As co-founder and CTO of Agitar, I find the "JUnit vs. Agitator"
subject he=
ading very troubling - so I feel compelled to jump in.  

Agitator *complem=
ents* JUnit; it helps you in performing broad
exploratory testing, and in i=
dentifying and persisting class and
method invariants (amount many other th=
ings).

I am a big fan and proponent of JUnit, and so is Agitar.  As a matt=
er
of fact, we brought Kent Beck on board as an Agitar Fellow a couple of
y=
ears ago.  I also gave 2 JavaOne presentation on JUnit (not
Agitator); one =
in 2004 and the last one just last week where I
co-presented with Kent Beck=
 himself.  Agitator takes full advantage of
any existing JUnit tests and ou=
r Dashboard product is also fully
integrated with JUnit.

So, don't think i=
n terms of JUnit vs. Agitator, but in terms of what
can Agitator do to comp=
lement my JUnit and TDD efforts.  Of course, I
believe it can do a lot - bu=
t I am hardly an impartial party :-).

JUnit is great for TDD which, as som=
e people noted, is more about
design than testing.  It's also great for cra=
fting very specific test
cases where you can use your intuition and underst=
anding of the domain
space and implementation to cover interesting scenario=
s and sequences.

Agitator is great for exploratory testing, subjecting you=
r code to all
sorts of inputs - both valid and invalid - which helps you th=
ink about
corner cases and conditions that you might have overlooked. It's =
also
uniquely capable in discovering and enforcing class and method
invaria=
nts (i.e. properties of the code that should *always* be true -
as opposed =
to the more specific cases people typically write in JUnit).

Bottom line: =
 Think in terms of JUnit + Agitator and not JUnit vs.
Agitator.

Thanks,

A=
lberto Savoia
